tagDescription: Royal Naval Officers employed under Dominion Government

Control and regulation of the waters of the Niagara River 1902-1911 -Preservation of Niagara Falls

1860: Wood Island on the Labrador coast. Question of ownership (see also correspondence 21-4-26) 1889: Boundary between Canada and Newfoundland in the Peninsula of Labrado 1903: Issue of licence by Newfoundland Government to cut wood on lands claimed to be within jurisdiction of Province of Quebec 1922: Action of C.G.S. Acadia and Schooner Corsair carrying out survey operation for Department of Justice Newfoundlands complaints re  1936: Survey of North Labrador by Dr. Alexander Forbes. Letter from Sir Wilfred Grenville asking for recognition of Dr. Forbes services

Imperial officers and NCO,s seconded for temporary service under Canadian government. Details re individual appointments -Nominal roll of NCOs of Imperial army serving in Canada -Appointment of Colonel W.G. Gwatkin as Chief of the General Staff, Canadian militia. Grant of rank in Canadian army of Major General. Substantive rank of Major General in regular army recommended by Sir Sam Hughes (refused) Appointment of Major General J.H. MacBrien as Chief of the General Staff (1902) -Case of Mr. H.G. Peacocke, late accountant, Barrack stored branch, R.C.A.S.C.

Attachment of Canadian officers and men to regular army units: Of Imperial officers and men to Canadian Military Forces -For annual training while on leave -For instruction at own expense, -On invitation from affiliated regiment -Members of County of London Yeomanry and Territorial Forces under special arrangement

Rules for the observance of the duties of neutrality -Position of British subjects under Foreign Enlistment Act -Purchase of war vessels by belligerent states -Prize cargoes. South African War Trophies -City of Ottawas application, etc
